On this page

Contributing Guidelines â€‹

How to Contribute â€‹

We welcome contributions to the Julia Auction System! This guide will help you get started.

Code of Conduct â€‹

Please be respectful and constructive in all interactions. We're building something together!

Getting Started â€‹

  1. Fork the repository on GitHub
  2. Clone your fork locally:
    bash
    git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/julia-auction.git
cd julia-auction
  3. Add upstream remote:
    bash
    git remote add upstream https://github.com/julia-auction/julia-auction.git
  4. Create a feature branch:
    bash
    git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

Making Changes â€‹

Before You Start â€‹

  • Check existing issues and pull requests
  • For major changes, open an issue first to discuss
  • Ensure your Julia version is 1.9+

Development Process â€‹

  1. Write tests first (TDD encouraged)
  2. Implement your feature
  3. Run tests locally:
    bash
    julia --project=. -e 'using Pkg; Pkg.test()'
  4. Check style compliance:
    bash
    julia --project=. scripts/check_style.jl
  5. Update documentation if needed

Commit Guidelines â€‹

Format your commit messages as:

type(scope): brief description

Longer explanation if needed.

Fixes #123

Types:

  • feat: New feature
  • fix: Bug fix
  • docs: Documentation only
  • style: Code style changes
  • refactor: Code refactoring
  • test: Test additions/changes
  • chore: Build process or auxiliary tool changes

Example:

feat(auction): add support for Dutch auctions

Implements descending price auctions with configurable
price decrements and time intervals.

Fixes #456

Submitting Changes â€‹

Pull Request Process â€‹

  1. Update your branch:

    bash
    git fetch upstream
git rebase upstream/master

  2. Push to your fork:

    bash
    git push origin feature/your-feature-name

  3. Create Pull Request on GitHub

PR Requirements â€‹

Your PR should:

  • âœ… Have a clear title and description
  • âœ… Reference any related issues
  • âœ… Pass all CI checks
  • âœ… Include tests for new functionality
  • âœ… Update documentation as needed
  • âœ… Follow our style guide

PR Template â€‹

markdown
## Description
Brief description of changes

## Type of Change
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] New feature
- [ ] Breaking change
- [ ] Documentation update

## Testing
- [ ] Tests pass locally
- [ ] New tests added
- [ ] Existing tests updated

## Checklist
- [ ] Code follows style guide
- [ ] Self-reviewed code
- [ ] Documentation updated
- [ ] No new warnings

Testing Guidelines â€‹

Writing Tests â€‹

julia
using Test

@testset "Feature Tests" begin
    @testset "Normal cases" begin
        # Test expected behavior
        @test function_under_test(input) == expected_output
    end
    
    @testset "Edge cases" begin
        # Test boundaries and special cases
        @test_throws ErrorType function_under_test(invalid_input)
    end
    
    @testset "Performance" begin
        # Test performance requirements
        @test @elapsed function_under_test(input) < 0.010  # 10ms
    end
end

Test Coverage â€‹

Aim for >90% code coverage:

bash
julia --project=. -e 'using Pkg; Pkg.test(coverage=true)'

Documentation â€‹

Documenting Functions â€‹

julia
"""
    function_name(param1::Type1, param2::Type2) -> ReturnType

Brief description of what the function does.

# Arguments
- `param1::Type1`: Description of param1
- `param2::Type2`: Description of param2

# Returns
- `ReturnType`: Description of return value

# Throws
- `ErrorType`: When this error occurs

# Examples
```julia
result = function_name(value1, value2)

See Also â€‹

  • related_function """ function function_name(param1::Type1, param2::Type2)::ReturnType

    Implementation â€‹

end


### Updating Documentation

1. Edit files in `docs/src/`
2. Build locally to test:
   ```bash
   julia --project=docs docs/make.jl
  1. View at docs/build/index.html

Review Process â€‹

What We Look For â€‹

  • Correctness: Does it work as intended?
  • Performance: Does it meet performance requirements?
  • Style: Does it follow our conventions?
  • Tests: Are there adequate tests?
  • Documentation: Is it well documented?

Review Timeline â€‹

  • Initial review: Within 3 business days
  • Follow-up reviews: Within 1 business day
  • Small fixes: Often same day

Getting Help â€‹

Resources â€‹

  • Development Guide
  • API Documentation

Communication Channels â€‹

  • GitHub Issues: Bug reports and feature requests
  • GitHub Discussions: Questions and discussions
  • Discord: Real-time chat (link in README)

Recognition â€‹

Contributors are recognized in:

  • The CONTRIBUTORS file
  • Release notes
  • The project README

Thank you for contributing! ðŸŽ‰
